Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Comprehend a simple spoken text, with teacher support
Elaboration: Understanding and responding to a range of common questions on personal or familiar topics, for example when asked ‘What is your favourite colour?’ and ‘What is your name?’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Comprehend a simple spoken text, with teacher support
Elaboration: Understanding common phrases and sentences for social and school purposes, for example ‘I would like …’ and ‘I need some help.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract essential information from short, simple spoken texts relevant to personal experience, with teacher support
Elaboration: Understanding short and simply structured spoken texts, such as instructions read by the teacher and a recount from a peer

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract essential information from short, simple spoken texts relevant to personal experience, with teacher support
Elaboration: Understanding common vocabulary, including frequently used classroom words and learnt topic words

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in familiar social and school routines, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using a range of common greetings and responses, for example ‘How are you today?’, ‘Fine.’ and ‘Good, thanks.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in familiar social and school routines, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using familiar or formulaic phrases and sentences when making statements or responding to questions, for example ‘My name is …’ and ‘Nice to meet you.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in familiar social and school routines, with teacher support
Elaboration: Borrowing words or phrases from a question to respond; for example, Teacher: ‘What is your favourite sport?’ Student: ‘My favourite sport is …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in familiar social and school routines, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using common sentence structures; for example, Teacher: ‘What do you like to do on the weekends?’ Student: ‘I like to do sport on the weekends.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in familiar social and school routines, with teacher support
Elaboration: Asking questions and following instructions to meet personal needs; for example, enquiring where to find resources or what colour of pen to use

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Present a simple prepared response on a familiar topic, with teacher support
Elaboration: Presenting a short rehearsed talk on a familiar topic; for example, giving a description of their family

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Present a simple prepared response on a familiar topic, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using familiar and rehearsed responses for common interactions; for example, recounting what they did on the weekend

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Present a simple prepared response on a familiar topic, with teacher support
Elaboration: Developing fluency in familiar situations (e.g. when introducing themselves) and adapting responses to altered situations (e.g. when introducing a friend)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Comprehend and produce a small range of short, spoken text types and structures
Elaboration: Understanding and producing short texts, such as simple recounts, descriptions and instructions, for different purposes

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Comprehend and produce a small range of short, spoken text types and structures
Elaboration: Identifying basic text structures such as introduction, body and conclusion

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Sequence events chronologically using time markers
Elaboration: Using a narrow range of time markers such as ‘yesterday’, ‘last week’ and ‘on the weekend’ to indicate specific moments in the past, present and future

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Sequence events chronologically using time markers
Elaboration: Using some coordinating conjunctions such as ‘and’ and ‘but’ to connect clauses, for example ‘I caught a bus and then walked.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Sequence events chronologically using time markers
Elaboration: Using some common subordinating conjunctions (such as ‘after’ and ‘because’) to connect clauses, for example ‘After we ate lunch, we played a game.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use different verb forms, with some consistency
Elaboration: Using a range of common verb tenses for familiar verbs, including present simple tense (e.g. ‘walk’ and ‘go’) and present continuous tense (e.g. ‘is walking’ and ‘is going’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use different verb forms, with some consistency
Elaboration: Using some regular and common irregular past tenses, for example ‘walked’ and ‘went’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use different verb forms, with some consistency
Elaboration: Beginning commands with an imperative verb (e.g. ‘Come over here, please.’ and ‘Bring that.’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use different verb forms, with some consistency
Elaboration: Developing positive and negative statements using subject–verb constructions, for example ‘I didn’t finish.’ and ‘The bus arrived.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a small range of common descriptive language
Elaboration: Constructing simple noun groups with adjectives and simple possessive pronouns, for example ‘a yellow car’ and ‘my friend’s house’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a small range of common descriptive language
Elaboration: Constructing noun groups using describers and classifiers, for example ‘tall trees’ and ‘native trees’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a small range of common descriptive language
Elaboration: Using prepositions such as ‘in’, ‘on’ and ‘at’ to indicate time and place, for example in ‘on Monday’ and ‘in Melbourne’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and use key vocabulary and ideas from short, familiar spoken texts, supported by context
Elaboration: Recognising familiar and learnt vocabulary in short spoken texts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and use key vocabulary and ideas from short, familiar spoken texts, supported by context
Elaboration: Using contextual information, including illustrations, vocabulary lists and print texts, to identify key ideas and predict vocabulary

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and use key vocabulary and ideas from short, familiar spoken texts, supported by context
Elaboration: Recalling and applying a range of words related to familiar topics; for example, using words related to family, school, colours, numbers, days and months

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and use key vocabulary and ideas from short, familiar spoken texts, supported by context
Elaboration: Using common synonyms (such as ‘fast’ and ‘quick’) and antonyms (such as ‘fast’ and ‘slow’) to communicate a range of meanings

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and use key vocabulary and ideas from short, familiar spoken texts, supported by context
Elaboration: Connecting a small number of words from a lexical set, for example for ‘soccer’, ‘ball’, ‘team’ and ‘match’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and reproduce pronunciation patterns
Elaboration: Pronouncing common words and learnt words used in interpersonal interactions, classroom situations and content learning

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and reproduce pronunciation patterns
Elaboration: Blending and segmenting sounds in words, for example ‘b-r-o-th-er’ and ‘c-l-ou-d-y’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and reproduce pronunciation patterns
Elaboration: Deleting and substituting phonemes (the smallest units of sound in words) to form new words; for example, substituting the ‘scr’ in ‘scratch’ with new initial sounds to form words such as ‘catch’, ‘batch’ and ‘hatch’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and reproduce pronunciation patterns
Elaboration: Substituting a middle sound to form a new word; for example, changing ‘stack’ to ‘stick’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and reproduce stress and intonation patterns with greater confidence and fluency
Elaboration: Using word stress, rhythm and intonation in familiar interactions; for example, using rising intonation for questions and stressing key words for emphasis

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and reproduce stress and intonation patterns with greater confidence and fluency
Elaboration: Recognising emotions indicated by changes in intonation such as anger and humour

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and reproduce stress and intonation patterns with greater confidence and fluency
Elaboration: Using strategies to support communication and engage a listener; for example, making eye contact and using facial expressions and gestures

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise and reproduce stress and intonation patterns with greater confidence and fluency
Elaboration: Listening to audio books while following words on the page, then reading the text aloud

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify differences between aspects of spoken English and other languages
Elaboration: Recognising the sounds and words of English in interactions

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify differences between aspects of spoken English and other languages
Elaboration: Attempting to clarify differences between English and other languages

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify differences between aspects of spoken English and other languages
Elaboration: Asking the teacher or peers about appropriate behaviour in certain situations, for example ‘Should I use eye contact?’ and ‘Is it okay to shake hands?’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify differences between aspects of spoken English and other languages
Elaboration: Exploring the nature of social interactions with familiar people and in known settings

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Ask for repetition or clarification to confirm understanding of spoken communication and ask for help
Elaboration: Attending to a listener’s body language or asking directly whether their own speech has been understood

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Ask for repetition or clarification to confirm understanding of spoken communication and ask for help
Elaboration: Attempting to re-pronounce words using different pronunciation, stress or pace

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Ask for repetition or clarification to confirm understanding of spoken communication and ask for help
Elaboration: Using a narrow range of simple, formulaic expressions to ask for repetition or rephrasing, for example ‘Please repeat.’ and ‘What does it mean?’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources when listening and speaking
Elaboration: Asking for clarification from other home language speakers

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources when listening and speaking
Elaboration: Asking home language peers to explain an idea in a home language and asking for a translation into English

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources when listening and speaking
Elaboration: Formulating questions in English and a home language to clarify classroom instructions or new ideas and vocabulary

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Listen and speak appropriately during small-group interactions
Elaboration: Listening and identifying topics and functions of group interactions such as to discuss ideas or to allocate tasks

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Listen and speak appropriately during small-group interactions
Elaboration: Performing a range of collaborative functions using simple language; for example, affirming (such as ‘yes’ and ‘good’), disagreeing (such as ‘no’ and ‘no good’) and staging (such as ‘next’ and ‘okay’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Listen and speak appropriately during small-group interactions
Elaboration: Using a home language to help learning, for example by taking notes or writing down key vocabulary

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the main themes or ideas of familiar and unfamiliar texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Reading a narrow range of familiar text types such as simple recount, narrative and procedure

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the main themes or ideas of familiar and unfamiliar texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Understanding classroom labels, such as those on lockers or desks, and signs around the school, such as ‘front office’ and ‘toilets’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the main themes or ideas of familiar and unfamiliar texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Understanding the main ideas in a range of familiar and unfamiliar texts, for example in their own writing, peers’ writing and the teacher’s writing

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand the main themes or ideas of familiar and unfamiliar texts, with teacher support
Elaboration: Applying subject knowledge and understanding of common or learnt vocabulary to understand the main meaning of a short text

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract specific information from a range of simple texts based on predictable language structures and vocabulary, with teacher support
Elaboration: Following print instructions to conduct a simple task or experiment, for example in a science lesson on magnets

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract specific information from a range of simple texts based on predictable language structures and vocabulary, with teacher support
Elaboration: Understanding key words in questions or instructions, and matching these to illustrations

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract specific information from a range of simple texts based on predictable language structures and vocabulary, with teacher support
Elaboration: Finding information in a digital text by following hyperlinks and headings

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract specific information from a range of simple texts based on predictable language structures and vocabulary, with teacher support
Elaboration: Dramatising or drawing parts of a story

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract specific information from a range of simple texts based on predictable language structures and vocabulary, with teacher support
Elaboration: Answering simple or ‘true or false’ questions or sequencing information

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract specific information from a range of simple texts based on predictable language structures and vocabulary, with teacher support
Elaboration: Summarising key points or representing information in a visual form

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract specific information from simple charts, tables or maps, with teacher support
Elaboration: Locating city or country names on a map

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract specific information from simple charts, tables or maps, with teacher support
Elaboration: Identifying information in a cell of a table by using row and column headings

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Extract specific information from simple charts, tables or maps, with teacher support
Elaboration: Pointing to and reading out the names of features on a labelled diagram

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use contextual cues to work out the literal meaning of unfamiliar words in a simple text, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using information in a text, such as images or descriptions, to deduce meanings

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use contextual cues to work out the literal meaning of unfamiliar words in a simple text, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using background or content knowledge to deduce meanings of words or phrases

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use organisational and visual elements to suggest the content of a text
Elaboration: Categorising texts as either fiction or non-fiction

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use organisational and visual elements to suggest the content of a text
Elaboration: Suggesting the purpose and audience of a range of common news media texts such as websites, news reports, opinion columns and persuasive letters

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use organisational and visual elements to suggest the content of a text
Elaboration: Recognising the function of features of an instructional text such as a title, illustrations and imperative verbs

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use organisational and visual elements to suggest the content of a text
Elaboration: Referring to visuals such as text titles, supporting pictures, graphs and charts to predict and locate content in a text

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use organisational and visual elements to suggest the content of a text
Elaboration: Using organisational or visual features to preview or summarise a studied text; for example, constructing a simple dot-point list or mind map

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use organisational and visual elements to suggest the content of a text
Elaboration: Using organisational features such as layout, illustrations and headings to find information in texts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify what is being referred to by simple cohesive devices in a simple text
Elaboration: Understanding common coordinating conjunctions (such as ‘and’ and ‘but’) and subordinating conjunctions (such as ‘as’ and ‘when’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify what is being referred to by simple cohesive devices in a simple text
Elaboration: Matching cohesive devices (such as ‘this’, ‘that’ and ‘those’) to the items they refer to

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise basic sentence and question patterns
Elaboration: Ordering words and phrases to create grammatical and logical sentences and questions

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise basic sentence and question patterns
Elaboration: Pointing out the subject, verb and object in sentences, for example in ‘She bought some fruit.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise basic sentence and question patterns
Elaboration: Identifying question stems such as ‘Who’, ‘What’ and ‘Why’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise common imperatives
Elaboration: Recognising and following classroom instructions containing familiar imperatives such as ‘read’, ‘answer’, ‘find out’ and ‘complete’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise common imperatives
Elaboration: Following simple sets of instructions, for example when asked ‘Read page one. Answer the set question.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand simple descriptive language within sentences
Elaboration: Understanding simple noun groups with adjectives (such as in ‘the small chair’) and/or simple possessive pronouns (such as in ‘my brother’s bag’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand simple descriptive language within sentences
Elaboration: Understanding describers and classifiers in short noun groups such as ‘small animals’ and ‘wild animals’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand simple descriptive language within sentences
Elaboration: Recognising common prepositions indicating time and place such as ‘in’, ‘on’ and ‘at’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise words for everyday items and actions, and topic-specific vocabulary that has been taught
Elaboration: Recognising in an unfamiliar text the topic-specific vocabulary that has been taught

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise words for everyday items and actions, and topic-specific vocabulary that has been taught
Elaboration: Identifying topic-specific words in environmental print examples in the classroom

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Recognise words for everyday items and actions, and topic-specific vocabulary that has been taught
Elaboration: Recognising words commonly used in classroom speech when they are printed in other contexts, for example on signs, on notices and in classroom texts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Pronounce a range of words comprehensibly when reading aloud, based on knowledge of vocabulary and phoneme–grapheme correspondences
Elaboration: Pronouncing basic vocabulary or phrases accurately and reading them fluently

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Pronounce a range of words comprehensibly when reading aloud, based on knowledge of vocabulary and phoneme–grapheme correspondences
Elaboration: Sounding out syllables and phonemes (the smallest units of sound in words) when reading unfamiliar words

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Pronounce a range of words comprehensibly when reading aloud, based on knowledge of vocabulary and phoneme–grapheme correspondences
Elaboration: Applying knowledge of phoneme–grapheme correspondences and familiar letter patterns to predict pronunciation

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Pronounce a range of words comprehensibly when reading aloud, based on knowledge of vocabulary and phoneme–grapheme correspondences
Elaboration: Applying knowledge of less common sounds and words with similar letter patterns to alter pronunciation when reading aloud

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Pronounce a range of words comprehensibly when reading aloud, based on knowledge of vocabulary and phoneme–grapheme correspondences
Elaboration: Reading words with digraphs in which one letter is not pronounced (such as in ‘knife’ and ‘thumb’) and using them in writing

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Pronounce a range of words comprehensibly when reading aloud, based on knowledge of vocabulary and phoneme–grapheme correspondences
Elaboration: Reading words with vowel digraphs (‘ee’, ‘oo’, ‘ai’, ‘ay’ and ‘ea’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Pronounce a range of words comprehensibly when reading aloud, based on knowledge of vocabulary and phoneme–grapheme correspondences
Elaboration: Using context to read the correct word when an unfamiliar word has more than one plausible pronunciation

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand simple punctuation when reading
Elaboration: Using punctuation to identify the nature of sentences; for example, identifying statements by full stops and questions by question marks

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Understand simple punctuation when reading
Elaboration: Using punctuation to identify parts of a sentence, for example by pausing appropriately at full stops and commas

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify differences in texts in English compared to home language(s)
Elaboration: Comparing the purpose, structure and language of cultural texts; for example, comparing a folk story in a home language to a folk story from another culture

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Identify differences in texts in English compared to home language(s)
Elaboration: Comparing the structure and conventions of texts used in the classroom to texts in other languages, for example for stories in 2 languages

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Select suitable books to read, with teacher support
Elaboration: Skimming part of a book before selecting, to check for familiar language and ideas, illustrations and amount of print

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Select suitable books to read, with teacher support
Elaboration: Comparing books with those previously read, to predict the suitability of topic, language, length and structure

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources when reading and viewing
Elaboration: Writing notes in a home language about meaning and pronunciation when encountering unfamiliar words in texts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources when reading and viewing
Elaboration: Using a bilingual dictionary to find translations of unfamiliar words, and noting these in a home language and English

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources when reading and viewing
Elaboration: Requesting help from peers or school staff who speak the same home language to find the meanings of unfamiliar words

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Draw on a range of home language resources when reading and viewing
Elaboration: Recording spellings, meanings and translations of unfamiliar words in a personal vocabulary list

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in teacher-led reading activities
Elaboration: Following simple print texts that are read aloud at a moderate pace

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in teacher-led reading activities
Elaboration: Expressing a personal response to a text (e.g. indicating enjoyment, satisfaction, agreement or disagreement) and giving simple reasons

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in teacher-led reading activities
Elaboration: Comparing events from a text with personal experience

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Participate in teacher-led reading activities
Elaboration: Transforming part of a text into an unfamiliar text type; for example, creating an illustration or poem from a story

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write short, simple texts for various social purposes, with teacher support
Elaboration: Writing a narrow range of short texts for various social purposes related to familiar experiences; for example, composing a ‘thank you’ text message or email

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write short, simple texts for various social purposes, with teacher support
Elaboration: Using model texts and templates to structure texts appropriately

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write short, simple texts for various social purposes, with teacher support
Elaboration: Incorporating some formulaic expressions copied from model texts (such as ‘Dear …’ and ‘Once upon a time’) into their own writing

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write short information texts on familiar content, consisting of simple sentences or statements approximating sentences
Elaboration: Writing a narrow range of short school-based text types such as descriptive, instructional and procedural texts

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write short information texts on familiar content, consisting of simple sentences or statements approximating sentences
Elaboration: Following an appropriate structure for a text, using model texts or templates for support

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write to communicate personal ideas, with teacher support
Elaboration: Writing a narrow range of texts to communicate personal experiences and ideas, such as personal recounts and stories

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Write to communicate personal ideas, with teacher support
Elaboration: Following the structure of model texts such as a greeting or sequence of events

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Label images using vocabulary learnt or practised in class
Elaboration: Labelling parts of a familiar diagram

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Label images using vocabulary learnt or practised in class
Elaboration: Matching vocabulary from a list to items in an image or features on a map

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise subject matter and attempt to use the structure of a specified text type
Elaboration: Structuring simple stories; for example, including a beginning, a middle and an end

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise subject matter and attempt to use the structure of a specified text type
Elaboration: Writing information under headings or in a template to follow a basic text structure

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise subject matter and attempt to use the structure of a specified text type
Elaboration: Sorting jumbled sentences into groups or short paragraphs based on related topics

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise subject matter and attempt to use the structure of a specified text type
Elaboration: Grouping related information and sentences to create a basic paragraph, although ideas may not be sequenced clearly within the paragraph

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Organise subject matter and attempt to use the structure of a specified text type
Elaboration: Writing a topic sentence making a statement about a key idea, for example ‘Cars are bad for the environment.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use simple cohesive devices to structure writing
Elaboration: Using common time and sequence markers to link and sequence ideas such as ‘Yesterday we …’ and ‘First we … Then … And then …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use simple cohesive devices to structure writing
Elaboration: Including a narrow range of coordinating conjunctions such as ‘and’ and ‘but’, for example in ‘I caught a bus and then I walked.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use simple cohesive devices to structure writing
Elaboration: Experimenting with some common subordinating conjunctions such as ‘as’, ‘when’ and ‘until’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use simple cohesive devices to structure writing
Elaboration: Employing pronouns to maintain cohesion and avoid repetition, for example in ‘Mary came to school early. She felt very tired.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use single clauses, or use simple coordinating and subordinating conjunctions to combine clauses
Elaboration: Constructing basic sentences using single words for subjects, verbs and objects in the correct order, for example ‘I learn English.’ and ‘Yesterday, we watched movies.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use single clauses, or use simple coordinating and subordinating conjunctions to combine clauses
Elaboration: Using noun–pronoun agreement, for example in ‘I like apples.’, with varying accuracy

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use single clauses, or use simple coordinating and subordinating conjunctions to combine clauses
Elaboration: Constructing compound sentences with a range of coordinating conjunctions such as ‘and’ and ‘but’, for example ‘They knocked on door but nobody answered.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use single clauses, or use simple coordinating and subordinating conjunctions to combine clauses
Elaboration: Constructing complex sentences using some common subordinating conjunctions such as ‘as’, ‘when’ and ‘until’, for example ‘When they arrived, they knocked on door.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Experiment with different tenses and use some common irregular past tense verbs correctly
Elaboration: Using a small number of common irregular past tense verbs accurately such as ‘went’, ‘bought’ and ‘woke’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Experiment with different tenses and use some common irregular past tense verbs correctly
Elaboration: Matching simple present and past tense verbs to time words, for example in ‘Today I have …’, ‘Last week we went …’ and ‘They always sit …’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Experiment with different tenses and use some common irregular past tense verbs correctly
Elaboration: Experimenting with more complex tenses, with varying accuracy; for example, using elaborated tenses (e.g. in ‘I have been to …’) and negatives (e.g. incorrectly in ‘They didn’t had …’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use basic qualifiers and quantifiers to express a range of meaning
Elaboration: Using basic qualifiers to express degrees of meaning such as ‘very’ and ‘a little’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use basic qualifiers and quantifiers to express a range of meaning
Elaboration: Using a narrow range of quantifiers to express amounts such as ‘some’ and ‘all’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a range of simple subject-specific vocabulary
Elaboration: Using related subject-specific terms accurately, for example ‘Tadpoles have gills and frogs have lungs.’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a range of simple subject-specific vocabulary
Elaboration: Matching subject-specific words to definitions or labelling diagrams

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use a range of simple subject-specific vocabulary
Elaboration: Combining known words to create degrees of emphasis or nuance, for example ‘very, very sad’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use graphophonic knowledge to attempt to spell unfamiliar words
Elaboration: Spelling frequently used words, and one- and 2-syllable words with common patterns, with reasonable accuracy

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use graphophonic knowledge to attempt to spell unfamiliar words
Elaboration: Providing the sounds for less common phoneme–grapheme correspondences such as ‘ight’, and using them in writing

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use graphophonic knowledge to attempt to spell unfamiliar words
Elaboration: Using knowledge of phoneme–grapheme correspondences and common letter groups to attempt to spell unfamiliar words

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use graphophonic knowledge to attempt to spell unfamiliar words
Elaboration: Using context and syntactic knowledge to spell homophones such as ‘break’ and ‘brake’, ‘ate’ and ‘eight’

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use graphophonic knowledge to attempt to spell unfamiliar words
Elaboration: Referring to classroom charts and a personal vocabulary list to check or confirm spelling

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use common punctuation with some consistency
Elaboration: Using commas consistently in lists or to indicate pauses

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use common punctuation with some consistency
Elaboration: Using question marks to indicate questions, with occasional inaccuracy (e.g. ‘She asked me to borrow a pencil?’)

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use common punctuation with some consistency
Elaboration: Correcting capital letters and full stops when reviewing their own or others’ writing

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use the features of simple text types appropriately
Elaboration: Using learnt text structures or model texts to begin writing independently; for example, attempting to use past tense in a recount

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Use the features of simple text types appropriately
Elaboration: Using vocabulary items that are appropriate to a topic and text in shared writing

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Revise and edit texts with support, incorporating corrections and suggestions
Elaboration: Following the teacher’s feedback to edit their own work; for example, correcting spelling and changing word order

Subject: English as an Additional Language
ContentDescription: Revise and edit texts with support, incorporating corrections and suggestions
